item.title: MSc Graduation & Thesis Defense: Advanced Machine Learning for Financial Fraud Detection
item.description:
Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Thesis Highlights
  • Defense & Graduation
  • Reflections

Introduction

On December 17, 2025, I proudly defended my MSc thesis:

“Advanced Machine Learning Techniques and Explainable AI for Financial Fraud Detection”
at the Warsaw University of Technology, Poland.

This thesis focused on developing robust, interpretable, and reproducible ML pipelines to detect and prevent financial fraud. It emphasized Explainable AI (XAI) techniques such as SHAP and LIME to provide actionable insights for decision-makers. The work addressed real-world challenges, including highly imbalanced datasets, noisy financial records, and complex sequential patterns.

Thesis Highlights

  • Designed end-to-end ML pipelines for preprocessing, feature engineering, model training, evaluation, and explainability.
  • Applied SHAP and LIME for transparent, interpretable model predictions.
  • Ensured robustness, reproducibility, and reliability for real-world financial applications.
  • Delivered actionable insights to improve auditing, decision-making, and fraud mitigation.

Defense & Graduation

The defense included:

  1. A comprehensive presentation of methodology, results, and insights to faculty and peers.
  2. A live demonstration of ML pipelines and explainable predictions.
  3. In-depth discussions on ethical AI, fairness, and practical deployment considerations.

I am honored to have graduated with Excellent Rank (highest grade), reflecting both my academic excellence and the impact of my research.

Reflections

  • The MSc journey strengthened my expertise in Graph Neural Networks, NLP, LLMs, and predictive modeling.
  • It reinforced the importance of robust evaluation, reproducibility, and explainability in AI systems.
  • Excited to apply these skills to AI-driven research, industry projects, and socially impactful solutions.

item.title: Advanced Machine Learning Techniques and Explainable AI for Financial Fraud Detection
item.description:
Overview

This MSc thesis project focuses on detecting financial fraud using advanced machine learning techniques combined with Explainable AI (XAI).

Financial transactions are highly complex, noisy, and imbalanced, making fraud detection challenging. The project emphasizes robust, interpretable, and reproducible ML pipelines suitable for real-world deployment and regulatory compliance.

Motivation

Fraudulent financial activities pose significant operational and regulatory risks. Traditional detection methods are often limited in accuracy and interpretability. This work addresses these gaps by:

  • Developing robust ML models that handle highly imbalanced datasets.
  • Ensuring explainable predictions for auditability and decision support.
  • Delivering actionable insights to financial institutions.

Methods & Work

  • Built end-to-end ML pipelines including preprocessing, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and evaluation.
  • Applied ensemble models, neural networks, and anomaly detection techniques to maximize predictive performance.
  • Leveraged SHAP and other XAI tools for feature-level and instance-level interpretability.
  • Implemented robust cross-validation and uncertainty-aware evaluation to ensure generalization under realistic distribution shifts.
  • Emphasized reproducibility, logging, and version control to ensure consistent results.

Results & Contributions

  • Achieved high predictive accuracy in detecting fraudulent transactions in imbalanced datasets.
  • Provided interpretable explanations for model decisions, improving trust and accountability.
  • Established a reusable and scalable ML framework for financial fraud detection.
  • Developed insights that can inform policy, auditing, and operational decision-making.
  • Work is currently under preparation for publication.

Applications

  • Automated fraud detection for banks and financial services.
  • Decision support for compliance and audit teams.
  • Scalable and interpretable pipelines for other predictive modeling challenges in finance and beyond.

Key Highlights

  • MSc thesis graded Excellent (highest rank) at Warsaw University of Technology.
  • Emphasis on robustness, reproducibility, and actionable insights.
  • Integration of advanced ML, explainability, and real-world financial context.

item.title: Low-Resource Tigrinya Language Modeling with LoRA-Fine-Tuned GPT-2
item.description:
Overview

This project focuses on low-resource language modeling for Tigrinya, using parameter-efficient fine-tuning techniques applied to GPT-2.

The goal was to build a reproducible, stable, and efficient text generation system suitable for scarce-data settings.

Methods

  • Fine-tuned GPT-2 (124M parameters) using Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)
  • Designed data preprocessing pipelines for sequential text modeling
  • Controlled training stability and reproducibility through fixed seeds and logging
  • Optimized memory usage and training efficiency

Challenges Addressed

  • Extremely limited labeled data
  • High risk of overfitting in low-resource settings
  • Evaluation of generative quality beyond loss metrics

Results

  • Generated coherent and grammatically consistent Tigrinya text
  • Demonstrated effectiveness of LoRA for low-resource LLM adaptation
  • Established a reusable pipeline for future low-resource language experiments

Applications

  • Language preservation and accessibility
  • Educational and linguistic research tools
  • Foundation for downstream NLP tasks in Tigrinya

item.title: Advanced Machine Learning Methods for Fraud Detection
XAI Graph Neural Networks for Molecular Property Prediction
item.description:
Overview

This research project focuses on predicting molecular properties using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), where molecules are modeled as graphs with atoms as nodes and bonds as edges.

The goal is to develop accurate, interpretable, and robust models suitable for scientific and industrial applications.

Methods

  • Implemented GNN architectures using PyTorch Geometric
  • Designed node- and edge-level representations for molecular graphs
  • Addressed noisy and imbalanced datasets through careful preprocessing
  • Built reproducible evaluation pipelines with cross-validation

Explainability

  • Applied GNNExplainer to interpret predictions at:
    • node-level (important atoms)
    • edge-level (critical bonds)
  • Conducted feature- and structure-level analyses for explainable predictions

Results

  • Achieved strong predictive performance across molecular property benchmarks
  • Improved interpretability without sacrificing accuracy
  • Enabled model inspection suitable for research and decision support

Status

ðŸ“„ Ongoing research project â€” publication in preparation.

item.title: Hate Speech Trend Analysis in Low-Resource Tigrinya Social Media (2018â€“2022)
item.description:
Overview

This project analyzes hate speech trends in Tigrinya social media posts collected between 2018 and 2022, during the Northern Ethiopia Tigray conflict. It combines machine learning, exploratory data analysis, and data-driven approaches to identify temporal and spatial patterns of harmful speech.

Motivation

Tigrinya is a low-resource language, presenting unique challenges for automated content moderation and linguistic analysis. Understanding hate speech trends is crucial during periods of political instability and armed conflict for research, humanitarian, and policy applications.

Methods & Work

  • Collected and preprocessed Tigrinya social media data
  • Developed ML-based text classification models to detect hate speech
  • Applied temporal analysis to study frequency and severity trends
  • Examined content length characteristics and moderation actions
  • Mapped geographic propagation of hate-related content
  • Evaluated correlations between conflict events and spikes in hate speech

Results & Insights

  • Identified hotspots where hate speech was most actively disseminated
  • Found strong temporal correlations with conflict escalation
  • Provided evidence for the need of tailored ML solutions for low-resource languages
  • Developed actionable insights for conflict-sensitive content moderation

Applications

  • Automated hate speech detection in low-resource languages
  • Monitoring of social media during conflicts
  • Supporting NGOs, governments, and researchers with targeted interventions

item.description:
I proudly graduated with a BSc in Computer Science and Engineering from Mekelle Institute of Technology, Mekelle University.

Here are some memorable moments from the graduation day and celebrations:

item.title: Moonshot Ethiopia Bootcamp
item.description:
Event
Moonshot Ethiopia Bootcamp
Date
June 1, 2019
Location
Mekelle University, Ethiopia

The Moonshot Ethiopia Bootcamp was a short-term international program that brought together students and staff from Thomas More University of Applied Sciences, Belgium and Mekelle University, Ethiopia. Participants collaborated on innovation-driven academic and development projects, exchanging ideas and working on solutions addressing societal challenges.

A total of 18 international participants and 20+ Mekelle University students and staff joined this program, fostering cross-cultural learning and academic collaboration in higher education and research.

This program emphasizes hands-on learning, innovation, and international collaboration. Click the Follow button above to see related updates.

Bootcamp Moments
